Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Dustin Ross is "Geometry and Physics Related to Virtual Curve Counting." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Yongbin Ruan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In terms of intellectual merit, the outcomes of project DMS-1401873 comprise numerous significant achievements in the PIs research area. The initial proposal contained two motivating objectives in 'curve-counting theory': to investigate the extension of Ruan's crepant resolution conjecture to open Gromov-Witten theory, and to investigate the generalization of the Gromov-Witten/Donaldson-Thomas correspondence to orbifold targets. During the tenure of the fellowhip, the PI published four papers related to these objectives. Each is described below.

1. "Crepant Resolutions and Open Strings" -- written with Andrea Brini and Renzo Cavalieri, and published in Crelle's Journal -- establishes the first class of examples of an all-genus crepant resolutions conjecture for open Gromov-Witten invariants.

2. "Cyclic Hodge Integrals and Loop Schur Functions" -- written with Zhengyu Zong, and published in Advances in Mathematics -- establishes the Gromov-Witten/Donaldson-Thomas correspondence for a class of toric orbifold surfaces.

3. "Donaldson-Thomas Theory and Resolutions of Toric A_n Singulariites" -- published in Selecta Mathematica -- establishes the first class of examples of the crepant resolution conjecture in Donaldson-Thomas theory.

4. "On GW/DT and Ruan's Conjecture for Calabi-Yau 3-Orbifolds" -- published in Communications in Mathematical Physics -- establishes the most general class of targets for which both the GW/DT correspondence and the all-genus crepant resolution conjecture are known.

In addition to the proposed projects, the PI also began several new projects related to the Landau-Ginzburg model and the Landau-Ginzburg/Calabi-Yau correspondence. This has led to four additional papers that have been prepared during the tenure of the fellowship. Briefly, these papers are:

5. "Wall-Crossing in Genus-Zero Landau-Ginzburg Theory" -- written with Yongbin Ruan, and published in Crelle's Journal.

6. "Sigma Models and Phase Transitions for Complete Intersections" -- written with Emily Clader and published in International Mathematical Research Notices.

7. "Genus-One Mirror Symmetry in the Landau-Ginzburg Model" -- written with Shuai Guo.

8. "The Genus-One Global Mirror Theorem for the Quintic 3-Fold" -- written with Shaui Guo.

In terms of broader impact, the PI has made a number of important contributions to the mathematical community. In addition to giving many invited presentations at seminars, conferences, and workshops, he has organized five conferences/workshops, emphasizing the role of young and underrepresented researchers in each, and he is now an organizer of the Geometry and Topology seminar at his home institution of San Francisco State University. Moreover, he has refereed numerous research papers, participated on master's, preliminary, and PhD committees, and is now serving as a PI for the HSI Conference: Broadening Participation in STEM at California Hispanic-Serving Institutions.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2017
Modified by: Dustin Ross
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In terms of intellectual merit, the outcomes of project DMS-1401873 comprise numerous significant achievements in the PIs research area. The initial proposal contained two motivating objectives in 'curve-counting theory': to investigate the extension of Ruan's crepant resolution conjecture to open Gromov-Witten theory, and to investigate the generalization of the Gromov-Witten/Donaldson-Thomas correspondence to orbifold targets. During the tenure of the fellowhip, the PI published four papers related to these objectives. Each is described below. 1. "Crepant Resolutions and Open Strings" -- written with Andrea Brini and Renzo Cavalieri, and published in Crelle's Journal -- establishes the first class of examples of an all-genus crepant resolutions conjecture for open Gromov-Witten invariants. 2. "Cyclic Hodge Integrals and Loop Schur Functions" -- written with Zhengyu Zong, and published in Advances in Mathematics -- establishes the Gromov-Witten/Donaldson-Thomas correspondence for a class of toric orbifold surfaces. 3. "Donaldson-Thomas Theory and Resolutions of Toric A_n Singulariites" -- published in Selecta Mathematica -- establishes the first class of examples of the crepant resolution conjecture in Donaldson-Thomas theory. 4. "On GW/DT and Ruan's Conjecture for Calabi-Yau 3-Orbifolds" -- published in Communications in Mathematical Physics -- establishes the most general class of targets for which both the GW/DT correspondence and the all-genus crepant resolution conjecture are known. In addition to the proposed projects, the PI also began several new projects related to the Landau-Ginzburg model and the Landau-Ginzburg/Calabi-Yau correspondence. This has led to four additional papers that have been prepared during the tenure of the fellowship. Briefly, these papers are: 5. "Wall-Crossing in Genus-Zero Landau-Ginzburg Theory" -- written with Yongbin Ruan, and published in Crelle's Journal. 6. "Sigma Models and Phase Transitions for Complete Intersections" -- written with Emily Clader and published in International Mathematical Research Notices. 7. "Genus-One Mirror Symmetry in the Landau-Ginzburg Model" -- written with Shuai Guo. 8. "The Genus-One Global Mirror Theorem for the Quintic 3-Fold" -- written with Shaui Guo. In terms of broader impact, the PI has made a number of important contributions to the mathematical community. In addition to giving many invited presentations at seminars, conferences, and workshops, he has organized five conferences/workshops, emphasizing the role of young and underrepresented researchers in each, and he is now an organizer of the Geometry and Topology seminar at his home institution of San Francisco State University. Moreover, he has refereed numerous research papers, participated on master's, preliminary, and PhD committees, and is now serving as a PI for the HSI Conference: Broadening Participation in STEM at California Hispanic-Serving Institutions.
